classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: You have vast experience studying and hunting creatures, allowing you to skillfully track prey.

Choose a type of favored enemy: aberrations, beasts, celestials, constructs, dragons, elementals, fey, fiends, giants, monstrosities, oozes, plants, or undead. Alternatively, you can select two races of humanoid (such as gnolls and orcs) as favored enemies.
You have advantage on Wisdom checks to percieve, track or gain insight on your favored enemies, as well as on Intelligence checks to recall information about them.
Your favored enemies cannot be hidden from you while they are within 20 feet of you.
You also learn on language of your choice spoken by your favored enemies, if they speak at all.
You choose on additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language at 6th level, and again at 10th and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: Your experience with travelling through and surviving in different environments lets you guide other through perilous terrain.
Your proficiencey bonus is doubled for any Nature or Survival check you make if you are proficient with the skill you are using.
Whenever you succeed on a Wisdon (Survival) check to track creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes and how long ago they pass through the area.
While travelling for an hour or more, you gain the following benefits:

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow your group's travel.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
Your group can move stealthily at a normal pace.
Your group has advantage on Wisdom (Survival) check to avoid becoming lost by non-magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while travelling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your speciality. Choose one of the following options: Archery, Defense, Dueling, or Two-Weapon Fighting. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

entries.name: Archery
entries: You gain +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

entries.name: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a melee weapon in one hand and no other weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that weapon.

entries.name: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of the second attack.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the magical essence of nature to cast spells, much as a druid does. See chapter 10 of the Playerâ€™s Handbook for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the ranger spell list.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these ranger spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of ranger spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the ranger spell list. When you do so, choose a number of ranger spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + half your ranger level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 5th-level ranger, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With a Wisdom of 16, your list of prepared spells can include five spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell cure wounds, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can also change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of ranger spells requires time spent in study and focus: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
